name: NewYorker
text: Jill Lepore writes about one historical record of the 20th-century struggle for racial justice: reports published by government commissions, which have acted as alibis for inaction. https://t.co/aKRJdm3lSh

name: NewYorker
text: The coronavirus crisis has brought to the surface what most inmates had previously only sensed, said a man incarcerated in a penitentiary with one of the U.S.’s largest outbreaks. “I always knew in the back of my mind: You don’t care at all about us.” https://t.co/H1F3p1Sqmq

name: NewYorker
text:
At a demonstration in Paris, a protester carried a sign that read “STOP KILLING US.” “This ‘us’ has grown exponentially and has become more vocal and more visible than George Floyd or his killers could have ever imagined,” Edwidge Danticat writes.
https://t.co/rlbuhGPx59

name: NewYorker
text: In the past two months, Donald Trump hasn’t led in a single national poll. https://t.co/1yAimy26J9

text: The closer an apple is to rot, the more rot it spreads—one spoiling apple speeds the rot of every apple it touches, and even of ones it doesn’t touch. https://t.co/cgbBRSVfAs

text: In a country where the highest office is held by a brute and would-be authoritarian, state violence is not an academic abstraction but a constantly looming menace. https://t.co/eDNLt6cLKx

text: "With just a few words and 13 photos of black babies and white babies holding hands, you’ve helped me understand race in a way that I, a black woman, have never understood it before." https://t.co/fpA0Mg2xmE

text:

text: "A hundred years after the U.S. occupation began, our désocupation has yet to come," Edwidge Danticat wrote, in 2015. #NewYorkerArchive https://t.co/9lx1vXqsmu

text: A new book revisits the life and legacy of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. https://t.co/ExcTFLVlqr

text: The classic ethical dilemma: Should you pull a lever and save five people or retweet a conspiracy theory about black-market ventilators? https://t.co/174UEvoASd

name: NewYorker
text: Over all, President Trump’s West Point speech was a recitation of military history, with a heavy focus on his favorite generals. One alumnus called it a “mashup of old war movies about places he doesn’t know or he’s never been.” https://t.co/hVtT0dwCql

name: NewYorker
text: “The energy is there, and the city is finally respecting what’s happening,” the photographer Isaac Scott said, about protests in Philadelphia. “Now I gotta get out there again. There’s more to come.” https://t.co/Z3tQdfYsgl

text:

text: In his documentary “And When I Die, I Won’t Stay Dead,” Billy Woodberry finds an original way to evoke Bob Kaufman’s remarkable life and work, even in the poet’s absence. https://t.co/9OTi7P6RDl

text: In April, Mike Pence lauded the work of a public-private partnership called Test Iowa, which he said would triple coronavirus testing in the state. Shortly after, significant questions about the program’s performance began to appear. https://t.co/8ZasbWvbU1
